The government's answer to the considerably growing amount of traffic on our roads is simply to back off, and they are not even attempting to treat the cause. This has resulted in more and more people now driving.

Do we, the western world (5% of the world's population), have the right to use the resources of the rest of the world at the environmental cost because we can't be bothered to get out of bed a bit earlier to catch public transport? Even if we did, then so does the rest of the world. This could have disastrous implications.

<|user|>Revise the following essay to enhance readability and clarity, while keeping the original wording as intact as possible.
Provide only the final essay.

Although Britain is said to have the oldest democrasy in the world,  however in many way this democrasy can be seen to be antiquated, old fashioned and unfair. There has not be whole sale reform of the electral system within Britain since women were granted the vote in the 1920's. This only alowed a growth in the electorate with the system of voting not having changed since the last century. This above all else can be seen to make Britain an undemocratic country.
The system used within Britain is known as the "First past the post" system. This is the system of direct constituencies. within these constiuencies the candidate with the largest number of votes is elected. This means that in many areas candidates are elected with under 50% of the total vote within that constituency. These successful candidate move on to the House of Commons to become MPs. This creates a house of representatives voted in by a minority vote in many cases (the only exceptions being for instance Huntington or Islington two very safe seats). This led the times when at a general election when parties have come to power with less votes than the main opposition party. This was the case in 1970 with the Conservative victory under Edward Heath. Many would argue that the weaknesses and unfairness of this system are apparent and that it should be changed. However there are strengths to this system. The first past the post system always leads to strong government usually leaving the governing party with a workable majority. Much of the work, to bring Britain into the modern economic world, done by the conservatives in the early 1960's was done through the first past the post system; The other option is proportional representation which is seen to give more say to the electorate on who get elected. But unfortunatly this system can lead to weak government allowing the growth of political extremist parties, through the ability to have a member of Parliament even with the overall vote. Also weak government, especially within Britains 3 party system where the balance of power would always be held by the Liberal Democrats and the National Parties. <|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Despite being often cited as having the oldest democracy in the world, the British electoral system can seem antiquated, old-fashioned, and unfair in many ways. Since the suffrage expansion in the 1920s, Britain has not undergone a wholesale reform of its electoral system, leaving the voting process largely unchanged since the last century. This makes Britain appear undemocratic to some observers.

The "First past the post" system, used within Britain, operates as a system of direct constituencies where the candidate with the most votes wins. This method often results in elected candidates receiving less than 50% of the total vote in their constituencies. Consequently, representatives elected to the House of Commons frequently come from minority support in their constituencies, with the exception of very safe seats, such as Huntington or Islington. In some cases, a party has won a general election with fewer total votes than the main opposition party, such as the Conservative victory under Edward Heath in 1970. Critics argue that the weaknesses and perceived unfairness of this system are evident and should be addressed.

However, proponents of the "First past the post" system emphasize its strengths, namely the creation of strong governments, as it typically results in a workable majority for the governing party. During the early 1960s, much of Britain's progress into the modern economic world was made possible through this system. An alternative to this system is proportional representation, which advocates argue gives voters more influence in the election outcome. Nonetheless, proportional representation can lead to weak governments, potentially fostering political extremism. This system also risks perpetuating a political landscape where power consistently resides with the Liberal Democrats and national parties, due to Britain's three-party system.

The British parliamentary electoral system is unfair and undemocratic. It is, however, in my opinion, the best way for the basis of government. Consider a general election, in which three parties stand, X, Y, and Z, in a country of 5000 voters. Supposing 2000 people vote for party X and 1500 vote for parties Y and Z. Party X would come into power because they had the most votes. However there were 3000 people who did not want them to be in power, which is not the majority of the country. Also, the idea of each constituency having an MP who fights for that constituency's beliefs in parliament. This has major flaws. Consider, for example, the MP who recently decided she wanted to change parties. Yes, I know it is the MP's belief's the constituents are meant to vote on the ideas of that MP but this simply isn't the case in many circumstances, the voter votes on how that party for which that MP represents is doing at the moment. Once a party is in government it is free to do as it likes, changing it's policies, until the next general election, at which point it will make hollow promises about what it will do when it next gets in power, just to gain votes.
It is, as I said before, the best system. Consider dictatorships, this falls at the first hurdle. With this system any madman can control a country, having economic disasters for not only that country but other related countries.

result:
The British parliamentary electoral system is unfair and undemocratic, though I believe it offers a good foundation for government. Imagine a general election where three parties, X, Y, and Z, contest in a country of 5,000 voters. If 2,000 people vote for party X and 1,500 for Y and Z, party X would win because it has the most votes. However, this is problematic since 3,000 voters did not want X in power, forming a clear minority. Furthermore, the notion that each constituency should have an MP who advocates for its beliefs in parliament has significant flaws. For instance, when an MP changes parties, it undermines the trust of constituents who believed they were voting for specific ideas, not the current actions of the party.

Under the current system, once a party comes into power, it is at liberty to change policies at will. This often leads to hollow promises made at election time to secure future votes, with no real accountability for the promises made.

The British parliamentary system, while imperfect, fares better than dictatorships by preventing any single individual from controlling a country, which could lead to economic disasters not only domestically but also for related countries.

No electoral system is entirely fair and perfect. The goal should be to satisfy as many people as possible, though not everyone all the time. The most just system of government might be achievable with a small group—around ten people—but even then, it inevitably leaves some people dissatisfied. The British parliamentary system is, overall, the best available option.

result:
Fox hunting is a 'bloodsport' and in my opinion, all such activities should be banned. Examples of 'bloodsports' include stag hunting, bullfighting, pheasant shooting, and even fishing. I believe fox hunting is both immoral and unnecessary.

The uniform of a fox hunter typically consists of a scarlet jacket, white 'jogpets,' a white shirt, a black tie, and polished black riding boots. From a distance, this attire may appear as that of some kind of gentleman. However, the fox hunt itself is a lengthy and extremely cruel process. The riders gather in what is called 'the meet,' which can last anywhere from 20 minutes to 90 minutes. At this point, the riders admire each other's uniforms and wait for the dogs to pick up a scent.

Once the dogs find a scent, the hunt begins. A number of dogs, ranging from 20 to 100, take the lead, with the riders following closely behind. Imagining the terror the fox experiences as it 'runs for its life' is difficult to conceive. If the fox strays from the woodlands onto other farmers' property, across roads and fields, the dogs continue to pursue it. This can cause significant damage to the countryside, resulting in knocked-down walls, gates, trampled hedges, and large 'hoof' marks throughout the area.

When the dogs finally catch the fox, it is ruthlessly torn to pieces, limb from limb. Rarely do the riders get a chance to see the fox, as it is already deceased by this point.

On the other side, farmers argue that foxes are pests and must be controlled somehow. Foxes are reported to kill sheep, hens, and scare other animals, leading farmers to feel justified in exterminating these pests. They also claim that the 'hunt' is very exciting and an integral part of their lives, arguing that there is no substitute for the 'thrill of the chase.'

Given these opposing viewpoints, we should discuss potential solutions. For instance, foxes could be controlled using methods such as a shotgun, which would be a much more humane approach to killing this animal than ripping it apart. Farmers might argue that they have nothing to do on Sundays, which is where 'drag hunting' could be considered.

Ultimately, it's crucial to consider humane and effective ways to address pest control without endorsing cruel practices.

There have been many demonstrations by activists when fox hunting is taking place, and although I do not agree with some of the animal activists' methods, I strongly believe that fox hunting should be banned in the United Kingdom. My reasons for this are as follows.

In my view, fox hunting is a brutal sport carried out by the higher classes in society. It is often regarded as a traditional practice, and it has been carried out for many years. However, I consider fox hunting to be a pointless and futile sport. Once, the sport may have been necessary to cull the numbers of foxes, but now that foxes have become so rare, they are rarely seen in the wild.

Foxes are simply hunted for fun and trophies, not out of necessity for food. Most farmers view foxes as pests and occasionally allow fox hunting on their land because foxes do cause problems by killing chickens or other farm birds. However, this is their natural behavior, and they must eat to survive and to feed their young. It is only rarely that foxes take the opportunity to steal chickens from farms. As a result, many farmers give permission for fox hunting to take place on their land.

I believe there is no point in killing a timid and rare animal. Foxes were once widely sought after for the making of fur coats, but public opinion has now put an end to this. I also believe that fox hunting is too brutal on the now endangered wild fox population. The foxes are not given a real chance; once spotted by the hunting party, a pack of hounds is sent after it. All the fox can do is flee in desperation. It cannot really stand a chance against the overwhelming odds of about twenty blood-thirsty hounds. Occasionally, foxes manage to escape or hide, but in most cases, once the dogs reach a fox, it will be torn to pieces.

Since the beginning of man on this earth, we have always detected, stalked, captured, and killed our prey. This was essential for our survival. In the modern world, there is no need to hunt in order to obtain our food. This raises the moral issue: 'Is it right and just to kill animals if we aren't going to eat them?' Are blood sports acceptable in today's society?

Then again, should foxhunting be considered a sport? The fox, by its nature, is a menace to farmers as it is a carnivorous predator and will eat the farmers' smaller livestock. Therefore, foxhunting functions as a modern-day 'pest control company,' whose role is to exterminate rodents and pests. There are, however, organized leisure fox hunts for fun, and the participants undoubtedly enjoy themselves immensely. Most of the fun is likely in the chase and not the kill. Some might argue that like recreational fishermen, the prey could be caught and released, but the hounds won't see it this way.

The pursuit of fox hunting comes under a lot of attack from pressure groups. Protests are all well and good, but the protesters have taken it too far recently. For example, in the first week of the New Year, a man and his wife were brutally attacked by a gang of protestors in front of their two young children. By doing this, the protestors are taking the law into their own hands and violating the very laws of inhumanity which they ardently advocate.

Banning fox hunting might drive the sport underground, and participants would find ways around it. The sport has always been under attack from protestors, and strong public opinion against blood sports doesn't give them the right to fight back literally. There is a strong argument that fox hunting is a national institution and a tradition which should be continued. However, I don't think it will be banned; the best we can do is have police on the scene to ensure that during a hunt, only the fox is killed.

The introduction of a National Lottery in Britain in November 1994 occurred only after a lengthy period of controversy. In recent years, several Private Member's Bills advocating for a National Lottery were presented before Parliament, but they were defeated in each instance. The National Lottery was introduced to Britain in November 1994. Since its inception, it has garnered immense popularity, drawing millions of participants each week. However, the introduction of the lottery has not been without concerns.

Two primary objections remain. The first is the financial burden it places on the working class. High society individuals, who can afford to spend £10-20 weekly on the lottery, are unaffected, but many working men and women, as well as the unemployed, cannot afford such expenditure. This issue highlights the financial strain the lottery imposes on those least able to afford it.

It is particularly worrisome because it is accessible to 16-year-olds, who are susceptible to the allure of instant wealth. Scratch cards, easily purchasable and enticing with the promise of immediate winnings, further exacerbate this problem.

Despite these issues, the National Lottery also offers significant benefits. It has funded numerous charitable and societal projects, from life-changing medical equipment for children with brain problems to the construction of new village halls in remote areas like the Shetland islands. The lottery has also created jobs, spurred spending, and inspired many to dream of financial success.

The National Lottery, like any institution, has its merits and drawbacks. Whether it should have been introduced is a matter of personal opinion, heavily influenced by one's weighting of these pros and cons. Personally, I believe its benefits to the country outweigh the negatives.

There were two main objections raised against the introduction of the national lottery. The first was the concern that the lottery would essentially act as another form of taxation, disproportionately impacting the poor.  Also the lottery helps to retain small shops and newsagents from being 'chased out of business' by bigger chains and supermarkets. Secondly, gambling is indulged in by many people on lower incomes, who spend large proportions of their income trying to win substantial jackpots, which could significantly change their lives.

Another positive aspect is that the lottery helps to retain small shops and newsagents from being pushed out of business by larger chains and supermarkets. Clearly, the National Lottery has its positive and negative aspects.

National Lottery draws have become a significant part of Saturday nights for many British families. Some people have become millionaires overnight by having their numbers picked. However, before the first draw was made, there was intense debate about whether the National Lottery should exist at all.

The debate also centered on which organizations would benefit from the Lottery's profits. While charities expected a reasonable share, various organizations made applications to the National Heritage Office, hoping to receive funds. Some money was allocated for the construction of a series of monuments celebrating the Millennium's start, though many people were wary of building 'White Elephants.' Sports teams, clubs, social groups, and communities applied for cash to build new facilities. When John Major announced that some profits would be used for a British Academy of Sport, there was concern that the funds wouldn't be evenly distributed, potentially exacerbating the North-South divide.

People often claim that computer games don't require a brain to be played. However, some games are so challenging that people consult each other around the world to figure them out. This collaboration is made possible by computers, which provide a much quicker, more efficient means of communication. Nevertheless, there are also computer games that require no brainpower, simply pressing a button. This represents a point where computers have stopped us from using our brains.

Despite the fact that computers save time, they perform a variety of tasks at the touch of a button. From solving complex equations to checking spelling errors, computers handle everything from simple tasks like homework to running a nuclear power station. At Heysham's Nuclear Power Station, for instance, one man operates the control room, while computers worth millions of pounds handle the rest. It is difficult to see how much brain power is needed for this.

In conclusion, computers can communicate with each other, fly planes, build cars, and potentially even run a country in the future. But at the same time, they also reduce the need for us to use our brains as much. It seems that computers both stimulate and potentially hinder our cognitive abilities.

The computer has been one of the most influential inventions of all time. Computers now dominate the majority of government business, science and communication, as well as many other areas of human life. 	The most obvious example of this is the calculator, an instrument used by mathmeticians and scientists for making numerical calculations. This has made it no longer necessary for the human to perform calculations and run through equations, and so need not understand the principles behind them any longer. This, unfortunately, means that the genius scientist is being replaced by the powerful computer and its operator, who needs only to know which buttons to press. This may seem an extreme view, as there is still much in the world of maths and science which a computer cannot calculate, but this may not be the case centuries into the future.
	Computers have been used as a means of keeping records, they have all but superseded handwritten text, (in a few decades people may well be faced with a computer screen and keyboard in their General Studies exam), they are used to transfer money across the globe, even to create artwork and to entertain. Computer generated pictures, including `fractal' pictures, drawn from equations, seem to be more popular than hand printed images from an artist's imagination, and computer games seem to provide more entertainment than any game or activity that takes place in the real, physical world. Virtual reality allows people to have `3-D' entertainment created for them by a computer.
	Whether or not the computer is taking over from the human brain, it has certainly made the human body all but redundant. People, businesses or corporations can be contacted at any point around the globe by fax machines, e-mail and the internet, and some people prefer these forms of communication to actually meeting face to face. Money can be transferred instantly without even needing to move the actual money - the physical coinage doesn't matter, it is the computer records that state how much each bank has ownership of.
	However, the idea that the human brain is no longer useful is not entirely true(!) Computers cannot deal with human beings, have no capacity for coping with anything outside their expected situations, and cannot adapt to new situations using judgement.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The computer has been one of the most influential inventions of all time. Computers now dominate the majority of government business, science, and communication, as well as many other areas of human life. In many ways, it has taken the place of the human brain in performing calculations and thought processes.

The most obvious example of this is the calculator, an instrument used by mathematicians and scientists for making numerical calculations. This has made it no longer necessary for the human to perform calculations and run through equations, and so need not understand the principles behind them anymore. This, unfortunately, means that the genius scientist is being replaced by the powerful computer and its operator, who needs only to know which buttons to press. This may seem an extreme view, as there is still much in the world of mathematics and science which a computer cannot calculate. However, this may not be the case centuries into the future.

Computers have been used as a means of keeping records and have all but superseded handwritten text. In a few decades, people may well be faced with a computer screen and keyboard in their General Studies exam. They are used to transfer money across the globe, create artwork, and entertain. Computer-generated pictures, including fractal pictures drawn from equations, seem to be more popular than hand-printed images from an artist's imagination, and computer games seem to provide more entertainment than any game or activity that takes place in the real, physical world. Virtual reality allows people to have "3-D" entertainment created for them by a computer.

Whether or not the computer is taking over from the human brain, it has certainly made the human body all but redundant. People, businesses, or corporations can be contacted at any point around the globe by fax machines, e-mail, and the internet, and some people prefer these forms of communication to actually meeting face-to-face. Money can be transferred instantly without even needing to move the actual money—the physical coinage doesn't matter; it's the computer records that state how much each bank has ownership of.

However, the idea that the human brain is no longer useful is not entirely true! Computers cannot deal with human beings, have no capacity for coping with anything outside their expected situations, and cannot adapt to new situations using judgment.

Computers may be the future, but what part will humans have in this future?

Moreover, educational levels in developed countries have drastically changed due to the technological revolution of the computer. On one hand, this shift has led to a decrease in primary and secondary labor sectors, such as agriculture and manufacturing, where robots have replaced human workers and computers now require only one supervisor for a production line.

There are various reasons why people in the UK may decide to stop eating beef. Firstly, it may be in response to protests at ports trying to prevent calves being exported where they may be used as veal calves and put into veal crates, which are uncomfortable for the animal and have been banned for many years in the UK. Scenes of calves in these crates or of protests (in which one protester has been killed) at the ports both on television or in newspapers may have persuaded people to either become vegetarian or at least stop eating beef. The emergence of BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy), also known as 'mad cow disease,' and the linked (or possibly linked) CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease) have alarmed consumers so much so that many schools have banned beef from the menu. Despite the risk of contracting CJD, which is minutely small and the fact that the number of cases per year has stayed roughly the same (i.e., is not increasing), the media hype has blown the disease out of all proportion, making people very wary of eating beef and causing them to resort to other products such as lamb.

The effect on the agricultural industry, particularly beef producers, is catastrophic. Prices have already decreased by as much as 20p per kilogram at auction, which is a substantial loss when an average beef animal weighs around 500 kg. Many farmers may go out of business due to this loss in profits or may diversify into other products such as arable crops. This may then bring the price of beef back up in the future; however, it may lead to problems of arable overproduction and increase storage costs for excess produce. As more farmers turn to arable crops, the prices may <increase>.

Thus, the effects of people not eating beef will have a knock-out effect throughout large areas of the agricultural industry. Beef producers would find it increasingly hard to make profits as they would have to increase sales to maintain revenue, while also incurring excess costs for food and other expenses such as bills. This may lead to labor redundancies, thus increasing unemployment and government benefit payments simultaneously.

In summary, the decision to stop eating beef is influenced by various factors, including ethical concerns, media representation, and health risks. However, the consequences for the agricultural industry are profound, affecting beef producers, prices, and potentially leading to broader economic impacts such as unemployment and increased government expenditures.

"In Vitro fertilisation" is the fertilisation of an egg in the laboratory, such as in a test tube. The egg is taken from the mother and placed in an environment optimized for fertilisation by sperm from the father. Once fertilisation occurs, the fertilised egg is implanted back into the mother's womb, leading to a normal pregnancy. Typically, multiple eggs are taken from the mother to increase the chances of success, potentially resulting in multiple births like twins or triplets.

Some argue against in vitro fertilisation (IVF), claiming it is not natural and raising concerns about the fairness to children born in this manner. They question the ethics of who receives the treatment, at what age it should be administered, and whether the substantial costs of IVF could be better spent on life-saving measures, such as vaccinations against diseases like measles. Proponents of IVF argue that it is a person's right to have children and that women who might otherwise be unable to conceive deserve the opportunity to do so.

The rapid advancement of technology has outpaced the development of ethical guidelines. As a result, it is essential to establish regulations. For instance, fertility treatment should not be provided to post-menopausal women, as the body indicates through menopause that it is no longer capable of carrying a pregnancy. Last year, a case was reported where a post-menopausal woman received IVF treatment by lying about her age, raising serious ethical concerns.

Science has significantly advanced since the 19th century. Many new inventions and medical breakthroughs have been made, and now people can successfully undergo liver, heart, and lung transplants. Modern medicine also allows individuals with insufficient blood supply to receive new blood, and those lacking white cells can undergo bone marrow transplants. These procedures are carried out on living individuals. In recent times, biological operations can even be performed on unborn humans.

In vitro fertilization (IVF) is a revolutionary technique where an egg is removed from a woman's body and placed in a test tube, then sperm is introduced to the tube. After a few weeks, the fertilized egg develops into a fetus. This process allows the fetus to grow and develop naturally within the woman's body, enabling the mother and baby to bond in a way similar to traditional pregnancy. IVF has been life-changing for couples struggling to conceive naturally, allowing them to experience this bonding and connection. However, I believe it raises ethical concerns, particularly when a post-menopausal woman chooses to have a baby. Nature's course suggests she is too old to have children. Such a child might end up with parents who are significantly older, which could lead to difficulties in maintaining a close, active relationship. Moreover, the possibility of the mother not living to see the child reach adulthood could also be distressing for the child. Additionally, the child's responsibility for an elderly parent could further complicate matters. The potential to select the baby's sex through genetic manipulation when the fetus begins development also presents an ethical dilemma.

There are many moral dilemmas surrounding IVF treatment. I will first consider its advantages. In vitro fertilization (IVF) is the artificial fertilization of an egg within the mother's womb. This process gives couples who could not naturally conceive the ability to have their own family without adopting.

**a) Fertility treatment for post-menopausal women:**
Fertility treatment for post-menopausal women enables parents to start a family later in life, allowing couples to develop their careers and achieve financial security before having children. This treatment also allows women who have divorced to enter new relationships with the possibility of having more children, which can sometimes strengthen relationships. However, there are concerns that older mothers may not be able to care for their children as they age, particularly if they experience ill health. I support fertility treatment for post-menopausal women but believe that upper age limits should be applied. Additionally, women should undergo counselling before proceeding to ensure they understand the increased stress involved in raising children later in life.

**b) Sex Selection:**
Sex selection, a form of genetic engineering, allows parents to choose the gender of their child. This raises ethical questions: should couples only wanting children of one gender proceed with treatment? While choosing children is not inherently wrong, it could lead to concerns about where it would end. If sex selection becomes acceptable, it might pave the way for choosing other traits, potentially leading to significant changes in the population. Moreover, if the procedure goes wrong and the wrong gender is conceived, parents may struggle with their feelings toward the child. In countries like China, the one-child policy has led to gender-based discrimination, resulting in the killing of baby girls due to a preference for boys.

By carefully considering the ethical implications and potential consequences, society can better navigate the complexities of these reproductive technologies.

The world of genetic engineering is a fiercely competitive and rapidly expanding area of science. The research in the last decade or so has made unbelievable progress at every turn, not all of it 'morally viable', so to speak. The idea that scientists should take responsibility for their work and its consequences is interesting but there is one fundamental aspect of human psychology that makes this hypothesis invalid; when an individual scientist is working on research, they are almost always working under sponsorship or directly for a company. This means that any responsibility they may feel for their actions is shifted to their employers or sponsors. This effect has been studied for many years, and several well-documented experiments show it clearly. For example, during World War II, German troops following orders to kill Jews did not hold themselves responsible because they had been set on this course by others. Similarly, people in positions of authority in many scientific situations often make decisions without facing immediate consequences, as they rarely see the direct impact of their decisions, much like Goebbels ordering the camps to operate from his office in Berlin despite being physically sick upon visiting the concentration camps.

While these examples are compelling, it's important to consider the moral obligations of geneticists. For instance, the production of insulin through genetic engineering is undeniably commendable, as is the creation of high-yield crops for third-world countries, another beneficial aspect of genetic control. However, it's worth asking if these innovations are as beneficial as they seem. For example, high-yield crops produce significantly more harvest than normal varieties, but they often deplete the soil, require careful management, and depend on oil-based fertilizers, among other factors. Are these plants morally reprehensible because they demand more care and resources compared to their more resilient counterparts?

result:
Genetic manipulation has been with us as long as we have been on the earth. Prehistoric man selected plants and animals which he could use, feeding them and allowing these plants/animals to survive and reproduce. This selection process is a form of genetic manipulation, and modern-day examples include long-term artificial selection of cows, dogs, and crops such as wheat. The beneficial effects are obvious, as yields of crops have increased through this process, although it is relatively slow.

Modern technology has enabled genetic scientists to clone and replicate genes through the processes of DNA replication. In this process, a gene is located, isolated, and inserted into a bacterial place, such as E. coli. Scientists worldwide are currently involved in the colossal task of mapping human DNA, a project that involves millions of genes on each chromosome.

The information gathered from this research has enormous implications, many of which are beneficial. There is potential to use this information to find cures for diseases, such as the gene that codes for resistance to cancer, AIDS, and other conditions. Already, this knowledge has enabled scientists to help those suffering from multiple sclerosis (MS), for example, who often have difficulty breathing due to a thick, sticky mucus in their lungs. Specially developed inhalers, developed using gene technology, can dissipate this mucus.

Genetic manipulation has also been used to increase crop yields, saving lives in third-world countries and reducing costs of raw food products. However, we must acknowledge that this information can be used for the wrong purposes, as history has shown with events leading up to the dropping of the atomic bomb during World War II. Nevertheless, I do not believe we should blame the scientists who developed the atomic theory, as many scientists are working in the dark, making new experiments as part of the nature of science. Inhibiting their work would hinder the benefits science can provide.

result:
Genetic manipulation has sparked significant controversy within the scientific community, presenting both advantages and disadvantages. One of the primary benefits is the ability to tailor organisms' genetic makeup to meet human needs. For instance, crops could be engineered to thrive in the harsh conditions of many developing countries, alleviating concerns of famine. Similarly, cattle could be bred to be more efficient at converting plant energy to body mass, or even genetically modified to resist diseases. In practice, some genetic manipulation already occurs, as racehorses are selectively bred, and gardeners crossbreed plants to suit their requirements.

However, the process of genetic mutation faces considerable opposition. While the potential benefits are attractive and would likely earn a scientist considerable recognition, concerns arise regarding the unintended consequences. The misuse of genetic manipulation presents significant ethical and moral dilemmas. Is it justifiable to alter an organism's inherent nature? Who has the right to "play God" and make such profound changes?

Furthermore, the unpredictability and potential uncontrollability of new organisms created through genetic engineering pose serious risks. While a rapidly growing plant might seem beneficial, it could disrupt ecosystems, depleting soil nutrients and hindering the growth of other plants. The theoretical responsibility of scientists in these scenarios is clear, yet the practical challenges of addressing the unknown ramifications of genetic manipulation are daunting.

Additionally, the testing processes involved in genetic manipulation are complex and fraught with risks. Already, we are close to a stage where genetic testing can reveal an individual's predisposition to certain illnesses, raising further ethical and safety concerns. These complexities underscore the profound responsibilities and challenges that come with advancing genetic manipulation technologies.

result:
Genetics has come a long way over the past few years. Scientists can now manipulate genes so successfully that they can literally create almost anything they want.

There are both good and bad sides to this. Starting with the good aspects, however, since this is the fundamental usage of genetic engineering.

The story that hit the scientific press two years ago was about the "Stay-ripe" tomato. It was an ordinary tomato with genes from a wheat variety added to it, creating a tomato that stayed red for weeks once ripe. This is a major advantage for supermarket chains who often import their fruit from French suppliers. The problem with this is that imported tomatoes often go bad in transport and are considered substandard when they arrive. The new tomato will not do this, so they get more tomatoes per cargo than otherwise.

There have also been stories about barley and other crops being genetically treated so that disease and pest resistance is inbuilt in the genes. Some can even produce their own pesticides, a trait acquired from another plant. These crops are ideal for third-world countries where their native crops are often destroyed by uncontrolled pests and they do not have the capital for large-scale pesticide projects. These plants could even be engineered to produce larger quantities.

However, genetic manipulation can also be used to recreate dead organisms. Due to government restrictions, creating or recreating animal life is illegal, but it has been done with a type of clover, usually found in southern France, but seemed to disappear completely.

People who believe that genetic engineering is going to recreate dinosaurs or create strange creatures are living in a dream world controlled by paranoia. This is all science fiction, not at all a fact. We are decades away from understanding how to do this, and even then, there is only a tiny chance of it working. So the harmful aspects of genetic manipulation are very few in number, and most people need not concern themselves with worrying about it.

The only foreseeable effect is releasing something with an effect that is unknown to those who release it. For example, it might kill off other plantlife or grow out of control.

Scientists should have an ethical code that they adhere to. For instance, experimentation upon live animals, especially humans, should not be undertaken. An example of this was the Nazi experiments during World War II, where they attempted to genetically alter Jews—a gruesome failure with many other similar atrocities committed by scientists since then. These people have always been shunned by the scientific community.

However, on the other side, many scientists don't receive the credit they deserve for their inventions. For instance, millions are made through the genetic engineering of crops, yet the scientists involved rarely get any money and minimal credit. Only the most careful scientists who secure the copyright before the idea is released get any credit. Unfortunately, these individuals are often labeled as nut cases, overly protective, or even heretics.

In general, scientists should have a moral responsibility to act like normal human beings, but they should not be blamed for any misuse of their final invention if they don't receive any credit for it. If a scientist does get the copyright and then sells it to the highest bidder, they must also consider the greater good.

'in vitro fertilization is the process in which an ovum or 'egg' is taken from a donor and then fertilized with sperm outside of the uterus. The babies produced are often refered to as a 'test tube baby' because they were concieved in a testtube and not in a uterus.

result:
In vitro fertilization (IVF) is the process in which an ovum (egg) is taken from a donor and then fertilized with sperm outside of the uterus. The babies produced through this method are often referred to as "test tube babies" because they were conceived in a test tube rather than a uterus.

There are two primary ways in which IVF can be performed. The first scenario involves using the ovum from the woman who will carry the pregnancy, typically because her partner has a low sperm count or is infertile. In such cases, a donor's sperm may be used instead. The second scenario applies when the woman is post-menopausal or infertile; in this case, a donor's ovum would be used. IVF may also be combined in situations where both partners are infertile. However, this practice is often viewed as unethical and fraught with complications.

IVF raises numerous ethical questions and concerns about the rights of all involved parties—the parents, the donor, and the resulting child. Firstly, there are differing opinions about the rights of parents to have children through IVF. One viewpoint suggests that people should have the right to pursue parenthood if they are able to do so. Another viewpoint argues that doctors should not have the authority to fulfill parental roles. Considerations arise when the woman is post-menopausal and the potential for her body to decline leads to questions about whether she should be permitted to have children despite her body "telling" no. Additionally, there's concern over whether older couples will be able to care for their children physically and mentally as they age.

Regulations for such cases must be carefully established, similar to those for adoption, to ensure the well-being of the child and the couple. An age limit and thorough evaluation of family history should be implemented to safeguard the child's future.

Another significant ethical issue is sex selection. The critical question here is whether parents have the right to choose the sex of their child. This topic remains a contentious issue, highlighting the complexities and responsibilities involved in reproductive technologies like IVF.

result:
In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is the process of fertilising an egg outside the womb and then implanting the developing foetus into it. The egg can come from the mother, often due to blocked fallopian tubes or following fertility treatments. It is also frequently donated or taken from an aborted foetus. IVF is the only option for many infertile individuals to have children, though it raises moral dilemmas.

IVF has provided hope for women unable to conceive naturally. Declaring infertility used to close the door on parenthood, but advances in technology have brought joy to many. For some, the purpose of our species is to reproduce, and IVF offers this opportunity to many more women. However, others believe IVF goes against nature, arguing that fertilisation should occur within the womb and seeing IVF as "playing God". Despite these views, women using their own eggs or those of others (with consent) should have the right to use these techniques.

One issue with IVF is egg donation. For example, if a friend donates an egg, they might later claim rights over a child they believe to be theirs. This can result in identity problems for the child. Particularly concerning is using eggs from aborted fetuses, as children born from these eggs may struggle psychologically knowing they originated from something that was never technically alive.

IVF is also costly. NHS-funded treatments could instead support more life-saving medical services, particularly when an overpopulated world still has many unwanted children. Stricter guidelines on IVF and an easier adoption process could significantly benefit these children.

In summary, while IVF offers life-changing possibilities for many, it also presents complex ethical, psychological, and economic challenges.

The invention of the computer, while incredibly useful, still necessitates the involvement of the human brain to provide instruction and insight. This emphasizes the need for human perception in recognizing problems and devising solutions. It is evident not only in data input but also in the design and manufacturing of computers. The ingenuity and creativity of humans led to the creation of these devices. Although computers can measure events more effectively than the human brain, they serve merely as tools and remain reliant on human intervention, particularly in scientific fields such as space exploration, exemplified by instruments like the Hubble telescope.

The advent of the computer has significantly reduced the necessity for manual labor, especially in the manufacturing sector. Robotics and automation have enabled production lines to operate efficiently without the need for breaks, sick pay, or other traditional labor considerations. While this has diminished the demand for skilled, specialized occupations, it also frees up the human brain, allowing individuals to pursue "higher things." This shift encourages lifelong learning and intellectual growth, as opportunities for non-skilled employment diminish due to increased reliance on machinery.

Furthermore, the rise of entertainment systems powered by computers has contributed to making human brains less active. From children to supposedly more learned adults, there is a growing obsession with games, which can detract from productive brain usage. Unless individuals engage in challenging games to improve their skills, such as advancing to level five, this trend undermines traditional learning processes, squandering time and energy that could otherwise be better utilized. Thus, while computers have brought about remarkable advancements, their impact on human cognition and labor remains a complex and multifaceted issue.

There are numerous reasons why people may choose not to eat beef or meat in general. Meat production is one of the least efficient energy conversion processes known to humans. result:
The primary reason for the people of Britain to stop eating beef currently is due to the threat of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSB), also known as mad cow disease. This viral disease attacks the central nervous system and can be transmitted to humans through consuming infected animal parts, particularly the brain. In cows, any signs of the disease necessitate immediate destruction of the animal, making it illegal to sell for meat. However, the symptoms do not manifest for a long time, complicating detection. While parts of the cow affected by BSB are often processed into fast foods like beef burgers, the rest of the meat, such as steaks, poses a negligible risk for disease transmission. The British press has exaggerated the issue, focusing on a small number of fatalities over the years.

Another reason for the decline in beef consumption in Britain is the growing trend toward vegetarianism, although this factor is less impactful compared to BSB concerns.

These issues could significantly affect the British agricultural industry, hindering both domestic and international sales of British dairy livestock. With the advent of global communication, fears concerning British beef could spread worldwide, as seen by France and Germany restricting or banning its import.

Despite the diversification of British farming, dairy farming and beef production remain vital to the industry. Any shift towards sheep farming or vegetable crops would necessitate substantial changes in the agricultural landscape.

There has been a significant scare in Britain recently that some beef may contain BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) which may lead to the human equivalent of CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). BSE is a disease in cows that affects their brain and spiral tissue (or offal as it is sometimes known). Beef sales in America have dropped by about 15%, and in Britain, they have dropped by about 6% to 7%. It would be very hard to imagine a Britain without beef, although not so hard to envision circumstances that may yet drive this outcome. For example, there has been a constant stream of scares about BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy) and CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease), with so many reports that much of the public has become blasé about them. For a report to be taken seriously, it would need the backing of the House of Commons and perhaps the European Community (EC). If this were to occur, the effects on British farming communities would be catastrophic.

Although beef rules have been steadily dropping over the past decade and beef still outsells many other varieties of meat, with the exception of poultry, the U.K. has always been heavily reliant on agriculture, and beef has always played a central role. If people in the U.K. stopped eating beef due to disease fears, farmers would face a suitable market problem. Selling in Europe would likely be impossible and too costly to sell further afield. Beyond human consumption, beef has few major uses. Essentially, they would no longer be able to farm beef, and attempting to switch to other animals, such as sheep, would be problematic due to market saturation.

As a result, farmers, veterinarians, drug companies, and food suppliers would suffer significant business cuts. While drug companies might shift focus to human healthcare, veterinarians and food processing plants would face considerable difficulties. Beyond financial concerns, farming is a large part of British heritage. Many farm buildings date back to the Middle Ages, and losing these would mean losing the farming communities and the towns and villages that surround them. All of this would contribute to a general downward spiral that would hit both the economy and the agricultural industry.

result:
There is widespread concern throughout the country over the publication of the Jakob Creutzfeldt-Jakobs disease, often referred to as British beef. This issue is affecting not only the agricultural industry but also the meat industry as a whole. The disease has been linked with many deaths throughout the UK, and its publication has gradually led to a decline in British beef sales.

Despite these issues, the government has made no attempt to reveal the truth. For instance, it has been found that a vegetarian who never consumed beef contracted the human form of Creutzfeldt-Jakobs disease and subsequently died. This lack of transparency has led to a decline in beef purchases and sales in butcher shops.

Beef has also been negatively impacted by the press, resulting in a major concern among the public. This situation mirrors the earlier salmonella outbreak in eggs, which nearly halted egg sales across the country. Although there was no concrete proof that people could contract salmonella poisoning from eggs, the bad publicity caused widespread fear. As with the salmonella incident, the industry eventually recovered, but it took some time.

The publicity surrounding Creutzfeldt-Jakobs disease has made farmers more vigilant. They are now required to monitor the condition of their cattle more closely. Only older cattle can contract the disease, so it is essential to check them and remove any that are infected.

result:
People in the UK may be hesitant to eat beef due to mad cow disease scares reported in the media. Little is known about the potential effects on humans if they consume contaminated meat. The public remains uncertain about whether the beef they consume is safe or contaminated. Even if beef is contaminated, it may not affect individuals immediately; it could take a long time or the cooking process might render it safe.

If the demand for beef in the UK decreases, there could be a significant impact on agriculture. A surplus of cows might result if people stop consuming beef, leading to the need for slaughtering and disposing of excess livestock. Unless these cows can be sold abroad, they would face waste.

Should people abandon beef consumption, they might also stop consuming associated products like veal, milk, and cheese. This would negatively impact dairy sales, causing financial losses for farmers. Wasted products and the need for government subsidies could become a crisis, forcing farmers to shift to different crops that are sustainable for their land and region. During this transition, beef substitutes would need to be developed.

The government would likely implement more rigorous checks on beef, especially concerning beef from cows affected by mad cow disease. The Ministry of Agriculture would need to provide definitive proof of the safety of beef. Extensive advertisement campaigns would be necessary to encourage people to resume beef consumption. Unfortunately, such campaigns might be less effective, especially if prominent cases of mad cow disease remain in the public consciousness.
